article_title: Dems wince at bitter Senate runoff
article_text:
Dems wince at bitter Senate runoff

Photo: Cynthia Esparza, For The San Antonio Express-News State Senate District 26 candidate Trey Martinez Fischer (left)...

Two Democrats vying for Texas Senate District 26 tore into each other again Saturday as early voting is about to start.

article_metadata.description: While Bernal pleaded for support without mentioning his Republican opponent Previtera, the two Senate hopefuls stood side by side attacking each other and echoing positive and negative advertising claims.  Like their taped debate for “Texas Week with Rick Casey,” the duo traded barbs over sources of campaign contributions and endorsements, with one moment of drama spawned by a question from the audience.  While versed in hyper-local issues such as streets, Bernal said he’s eager to tackle state topics including school finance, voting rights, health care and immigration.  Previtera continued: “I told him I would certainly never go negative, but I am going to show the differences in our opinions,” on topics including school choice, Obamacare, minimum wage and the city non-discrimination ordinance that Bernal helped craft as a councilman.  The costs won’t stop there because the two contenders for the Senate seat are both House members, and the winner will be replaced in another special election, not yet scheduled, costing about $150,000, said Elections Administrator Jacque Callanen.  Election expenses include personnel costs, operation of 14 early polling sites for up to 12 hours a day for five days, providing voting devices at about 145 polls; and canvassing the vote.
article_metadata.author.name: By John W. Gonzalez, Staff Writer
